THE NEWS.,ETTER
Vol. XIV. No. 13.
REGIMENT GAMES
—0—
Hopkins Well Represented. in
Joint Meet

FIFTH

The committee in charge of the
Johns Hopkins - Fifth Regiment
games, which will be held in the big
armory March 12, has planned the
greatest and best meet ever attempted in Baltimore. The plans alone
reflect much credit upon the joint
committee, and there is every reason to believe that this city will entertain the best athletes in the East.
Final arrangements were completed last night at a joint meeting of
committees from the athletic _associations of the Fifth Regiment and
Johns Hopkins University.
Invitations have been sent to every prominent university, college,
athletic club and all branches of the
Y. M. C. A. in the East and throughout the State. There is every indication that a record for entries will
be made.
George Washington University,
Georgetown, and the University of
Virginia have already given assurances that they will be well represented in the lists, and the Big Six—
Pennsylvania, Yale, Harvard, Princeton, Cornell and Carlisle—are counted upon to send representatives. The
New York Athletic Club and the
Crescent Club of Brooklyn, are also
expected to send athletes.
In all about 400 big associations,
representing all the grades of athletics—inter-scholastic, collegiate, associational and otherwise — have been
urged to take part in the meet. Entry
blanks were mailed last night by the
committee.
The joint committee which has
Planned this mammoth meet is:
Fifth Regiment Athletic Association—Major Washington Bowie, Jr.,
chairman; Lieut. Frank A. Hancock,
Lieut. George J. Turner, treasurer.
Johns Hopkins University Athletic
Association — Theodore E. Straus,
Harry Burgan, secretary; Joseph T.
England.
The` committeemen have been
meeting frequently during the .past
few weeks, discussing the meet and
formulating plans to carry it into effect, and last night's meeting consummated the project. The committee is making extra efforts to secure
a large representation from the big
Colleges, while at the same time
Pushing the inter-collegiate end as
far as possible.
The acceptances from major colleges' and from the large athletic associations are dependent upon a pos-

Baltimore, Md.,
sible conflict of dates, through the
committee has looked into this
chance obstacle and endeavored to
avoid any such setback.
One of the main features of the
meet *wilt be the holding of events
for the South Atlantic championships. These will include the '00yard dash, ioo-yard hurdle, 880-yard
run and running hop, step and jump.
All of the events will be scratch.
The finest athletes in these respective events are expected to be thus
drawn to the meet, while making the
meet additionally attractive for the
wen of unknown caliber, who will
participate.
cure the formost athletic authorities
of the East to attend the athletic
An effort is also to be made to secarnival and also to have charge of
the conduct of the events. It is particularly desired by the committee to
secure James E. Sullivan, of New
York, formerly president of the
Amateur Athletic Union, for referee.
Another big feature will be a renewal of the old-time rivalry between Johns Hopkins and the University of Virginia in the relay race.
This is assured. There was only a
2-foot margin between the two teams
when they finished a thrilling race
last year, and the struggle will be
equally interesting in the coming
clash.
Carlisle, according to one of the
committee, will also be represented,
particularly in the relay field, and an
effort will be put forth to secure
teams of the Indians' mettle to prevent the Braves landing the prize
with any degree of ease.
Internal rivalry, of course, will
figure largely among the athletes of
the Fifth Regiment, and the companies will be given a chance in closed
meets, to get their brotherly licks at
each other. Many, though, will be
entered for the open events and will
try for the big honors.
The events are:
Open handicap — ioo-yard dash,
220-yard run, 44o-yard run, 880yard run, mile run, ioo-yard hurdle,
high jump, pole vault and i6-pound
shot put.
Closed (for Fifth Regiment) —
Ioo-yard dash, 440-yard run, 880yard dash, 440-yard run.
Interscholastic events (for boys
under 18 years)-100-yard dash and
440-yard run.
Championship
Atlantic
South
events (all scratch)—Ioo-yard dash,
ioo-yard hurdle, 880-yard run and
jump.
Half mile relay (interscholastic).

THE NEWS-LETTER,

PHOTOGRAPHY BY
INVISIBLE LIGHT
There is a corner of the University with which the average undergraduate is but little familiar,—Prolessor Robert WiLiams Wood's Experimental Physics Laboratory. The
fact, so far has our ignorance of
what transpires in one of the most
important of the original research
departments at Johns Hopkins gone,
that the appearance of an article in
the February Century, entitled "A
New Department in Photography,"
has come entirely unexpected and
unheralded. The demonstrations and
experiments with "invisible light"
appeal to others than physicists or
Professor
indeed
photographers,
Wood has gone far towards putting
on a scientific basis the old adage
that "things are not always what
they seem."
We are all familiar with the old
experiment of the passage of a ray
of light through a prism, and we
all know that the spectrum thus
found shows a rainbow-like band of
colors which is bordered on one side
by red and on the other side by violet, but that there are other colors,
or rays, beyond the red and beyond
the violet, and which cannot be seen
under ordinary conditions, has only
been discarded in comparatively recent times. Although these colors
are not visible to the human eye, on
account of the light-ray -being too
long or too short to be recorded, they
can be detected by projecting the

spectrum on a sensitive photographic
plate in a darkened room. The light
registered on the plate next to the
violet of the spectrum is called ultraviolet, that next to the red infrared. It is of co-..rse impossible to
present all the examples and experiments as set forth by Professor
Wood, but in the accompanying picture some idea of the effect of the
ultra-violet light in photography may
i)e gained. The picture above is a
reproduction of a photograph taken
v-ith the infra-red rays.
It will doubtless come as a surprise to many of us to learn that
Hopkins is one of the ten most highly endowed universities in the country. According to the report of the
Commissioner of Education these, and
their endowments are as follows:
Leland Stanford Junior, $24,525,922; Columbia, $23,542,262; Harvard,

home of a social organization known
;is the International Club. The.president isai almond eyed Celestial; the
N,ice president is one of "the little
brown brothers" from the Philipines;
the recording secretary hails from
the Land of the Maple Leaf and lacrosse; the secretary is a Japanese,
while the treasurer is haughty Castilian.

February 14, 1910.

MEETING OF SCIENTIFIC
ASSOCIATION

DR. NYS COMPLIMENTS
DISSERTATIONS

The regular meeting of the Scientific Association of the University
was held of last week in Hcpkins
Hall. A large attendance was present to hear Dr. William H. Welch
of the Medical School, who delivered an address on the subject of "PreDr. Welch
ventive Medicine."
spoke from brief notes, and the easy
fluency with which he handled his
snbject was worthy of his known
as a lecturer. Beginning with
a brief reference to the sanitary
measures of ancient times, he sketched rapidly the development of tho
medicine
science of preventive
through the Middle Ages and down
to the marvellous results achieved
at the present day. He paid especial
attention to the epoch-making work
of Pasteur- and Lister and showed
how their discovery of the connection between bacteria and disease
had led to the modern science of
bacteriology and made possible raIll
tional preventive measures.
soire detail he told of the results already obtained by the use of antitoxin methods in various diseases, of
the triumphs of - modern sanitation
and disinfection, and of the increased length of human life and the
economic saving due to the prevention of disease, and concluded with
a plea for the interest of the audience in this work.

To the Editor of The News-Letter.
Dear Sir:
In the second column, first page,
vol.4,No. 13, of The News-Letter you
say: "Lowest in the scale of attachment (to the University) stand
these same doctors of philosophy.
More distant from the University in
time and space, finding their lot cast
generally in other institutions of
learning — universities, colleges and
schools—they have inevitably formed new academic associations and
have allowed their new environment
to dull their interest in the University which gave them their degrees
(MY italics.) Speaking for myself I
do not find this true. On the contrary, as time goes on and experience is gained I feel more anxious
that the University shall continue to
be what it was while I was in Baltimore, in 1877-1878--a place for hard
work, plain living and high thinking.
I am one of those who have formed strong interests elsewhere, but I
have congratulated myself that I had
became associated with the Johns
Hopkins University and all that it
stands for in scholarship. This attachment is like other strong emotions. One does not talk about them,
but they are felt the more strongly.
If the management takes the pains to
see to it that the busy doctors of philosophy know of university needs
they will not find us deficient in interest.
Edward Hart.
To the Editor of The News-Letter,
Johns Hopkins University.
Dear Sir:
In reading the News-Letter today,
I note with interest what is being
said in reference to the Honor System. While at college we took up
this proposition,and after a very close
fight decided that at that time the
plan was not feasible.
With certain objections you are
no doubt familiar. First that of reporting men whether they are
friends, enemies, or mere acquaintances, and this furthermore, promotes
feeling, if one should exist between
men not on good terms with one another. Another point is that, suppose a man who is in his last term
for his degree, whose future work
depends on his degree, cheats in
some manner, is convicted and expelled from college, the question
comes to my mind have we the right
to turn him away, to deprive him of
his degree, his means of a livelihood?
I doubt it exceedingly.
On the ‘other hand, in many re-

5
spects I think it a fine idea, and in
many instances has worked to perfection. It undoubtly advances the
moral tone of the student, reduces
the amount of underhand work, and
obliterates the spying professor, who
has his likes and dislikes. The Honor System is much better adapted to
a college with dormitories than to
one situated in a large city with students living at home or in boarding
houses. It is a big step to take, and
should have full considertion before
action is finally taken.
Yours very truly,
Alumnus.
To the Editor of The News-Letter:
May I give my reasons for opposing the ;,,,doption in the Johns Hopkins University of the so-called"Hon
or System," which several of your
correspondents have advocated?
Surely, when we reflect a moment,
we shall see that the present method
of conducting examinations is much
more of an honor system than the
system used in some other institutions, and advocated by your correspondents. At present the student has
simply his own will to keep him from
dishonesty in his examinations. There
are, to be sure, professors in the
room; but they show us clearly that
they are not there to watch us. Witn
the introduction of this new system,
the student has not only his own will,
but the fear of the penalty to keep
him from dishonesty. So the question resolves itself: Is it better that
a student be given a chance to control his own will, with his own conscience as a judge, or that he be
forced, by fear, to do right. The
one method gives the student the opportunity to strengthen his will-power or to weaken it; the other method
takes away this opportunity, and allows him neither to strengthen nor
weaken it. Which is the better? The
answer to this question depends upon
whether the proportion of students
who strengthen themselves is greater
or less than that of those who weaken themselves. From the observations that I have made, I believe that
at least ninety per cent of the students are perfectly honest in their
examinations. It hardly seems fair
that this vast majority should have
their opportunity for development restricted by the comparatively small
number who must be forced to do
right.
Student.

REGIMENT GAMES

Hopkins Well Represented. in
Joint Meet

FIFTH

The committee in charge of the
Johns Hopkins - Fifth Regiment
games, which will be held in the big
armory March 12, has planned the
greatest and best meet ever attempted in Baltimore. The plans alone
reflect much credit upon the joint
committee, and there is every reason to believe that this city will entertain the best athletes in the East.
Final arrangements were completed last night at a joint meeting of
committees from the athletic _associations of the Fifth Regiment and
Johns Hopkins University.
Invitations have been sent to every prominent university, college,
athletic club and all branches of the
Y. M. C. A. in the East and throughout the State. There is every indication that a record for entries will
be made.
George Washington University,
Georgetown, and the University of
Virginia have already given assurances that they will be well represented in the lists, and the Big Six—
Pennsylvania, Yale, Harvard, Princeton, Cornell and Carlisle—are counted upon to send representatives. The
New York Athletic Club and the
Crescent Club of Brooklyn, are also
expected to send athletes.
In all about 400 big associations,
representing all the grades of athletics—inter-scholastic, collegiate, associational and otherwise — have been
urged to take part in the meet. Entry
blanks were mailed last night by the
committee.
The joint committee which has
Planned this mammoth meet is:
Fifth Regiment Athletic Association—Major Washington Bowie, Jr.,
chairman; Lieut. Frank A. Hancock,
Lieut. George J. Turner, treasurer.
Johns Hopkins University Athletic
Association — Theodore E. Straus,
Harry Burgan, secretary; Joseph T.
England.
The` committeemen have been
meeting frequently during the .past
few weeks, discussing the meet and
formulating plans to carry it into effect, and last night's meeting consummated the project. The committee is making extra efforts to secure
a large representation from the big
Colleges, while at the same time
Pushing the inter-collegiate end as
far as possible.
The acceptances from major colleges' and from the large athletic associations are dependent upon a pos-

Baltimore, Md.,
sible conflict of dates, through the
committee has looked into this
chance obstacle and endeavored to
avoid any such setback.
One of the main features of the
meet *wilt be the holding of events
for the South Atlantic championships. These will include the '00yard dash, ioo-yard hurdle, 880-yard
run and running hop, step and jump.
All of the events will be scratch.
The finest athletes in these respective events are expected to be thus
drawn to the meet, while making the
meet additionally attractive for the
wen of unknown caliber, who will
participate.
cure the formost athletic authorities
of the East to attend the athletic
An effort is also to be made to secarnival and also to have charge of
the conduct of the events. It is particularly desired by the committee to
secure James E. Sullivan, of New
York, formerly president of the
Amateur Athletic Union, for referee.
Another big feature will be a renewal of the old-time rivalry between Johns Hopkins and the University of Virginia in the relay race.
This is assured. There was only a
2-foot margin between the two teams
when they finished a thrilling race
last year, and the struggle will be
equally interesting in the coming
clash.
Carlisle, according to one of the
committee, will also be represented,
particularly in the relay field, and an
effort will be put forth to secure
teams of the Indians' mettle to prevent the Braves landing the prize
with any degree of ease.
Internal rivalry, of course, will
figure largely among the athletes of
the Fifth Regiment, and the companies will be given a chance in closed
meets, to get their brotherly licks at
each other. Many, though, will be
entered for the open events and will
try for the big honors.
The events are:
Open handicap — ioo-yard dash,

shot put.

INVISIBLE LIGHT
There is a corner of the University with which the average undergraduate is but little familiar,—Prolessor Robert WiLiams Wood's Experimental Physics Laboratory. The
fact, so far has our ignorance of
what transpires in one of the most
important of the original research
departments at Johns Hopkins gone,
that the appearance of an article in
the February Century, entitled "A
New Department in Photography,"
has come entirely unexpected and
unheralded. The demonstrations and
experiments with "invisible light"
appeal to others than physicists or
Professor
indeed
photographers,
Wood has gone far towards putting
on a scientific basis the old adage
that "things are not always what
they seem."
We are all familiar with the old
experiment of the passage of a ray
of light through a prism, and we
all know that the spectrum thus
found shows a rainbow-like band of
colors which is bordered on one side
by red and on the other side by violet, but that there are other colors,
or rays, beyond the red and beyond
the violet, and which cannot be seen
under ordinary conditions, has only
been discarded in comparatively recent times. Although these colors
are not visible to the human eye, on
account of the light-ray -being too
long or too short to be recorded, they
can be detected by projecting the

spectrum on a sensitive photographic
plate in a darkened room. The light
registered on the plate next to the
violet of the spectrum is called ultraviolet, that next to the red infrared. It is of co-..rse impossible to
present all the examples and experiments as set forth by Professor
Wood, but in the accompanying picture some idea of the effect of the
ultra-violet light in photography may
i)e gained. The picture above is a
reproduction of a photograph taken
v-ith the infra-red rays.

brown brothers" from the Philipines;
the recording secretary hails from

To the Editor of The News-Letter.
Dear Sir:
In the second column, first page,
vol.4,No. 13, of The News-Letter you
say: "Lowest in the scale of attachment (to the University) stand
these same doctors of philosophy.
More distant from the University in
time and space, finding their lot cast
generally in other institutions of
learning — universities, colleges and
schools—they have inevitably formed new academic associations and
have allowed their new environment
to dull their interest in the University which gave them their degrees
(MY italics.) Speaking for myself I
do not find this true. On the contrary, as time goes on and experience is gained I feel more anxious
that the University shall continue to
be what it was while I was in Baltimore, in 1877-1878--a place for hard
work, plain living and high thinking.
I am one of those who have formed strong interests elsewhere, but I
have congratulated myself that I had
became associated with the Johns
Hopkins University and all that it
stands for in scholarship. This attachment is like other strong emotions. One does not talk about them,
but they are felt the more strongly.
If the management takes the pains to
see to it that the busy doctors of philosophy know of university needs
they will not find us deficient in interest.
Edward Hart.
To the Editor of The News-Letter,
Johns Hopkins University.
Dear Sir:
In reading the News-Letter today,
I note with interest what is being
said in reference to the Honor System. While at college we took up
this proposition,and after a very close
fight decided that at that time the
plan was not feasible.
With certain objections you are
no doubt familiar. First that of reporting men whether they are
friends, enemies, or mere acquaintances, and this furthermore, promotes
feeling, if one should exist between
men not on good terms with one another. Another point is that, suppose a man who is in his last term
for his degree, whose future work
depends on his degree, cheats in
some manner, is convicted and expelled from college, the question
comes to my mind have we the right
to turn him away, to deprive him of
his degree, his means of a livelihood?
I doubt it exceedingly.
On the ‘other hand, in many re-

5
spects I think it a fine idea, and in
many instances has worked to perfection. It undoubtly advances the
moral tone of the student, reduces
the amount of underhand work, and
obliterates the spying professor, who
has his likes and dislikes. The Honor System is much better adapted to
a college with dormitories than to
one situated in a large city with students living at home or in boarding
houses. It is a big step to take, and
should have full considertion before
action is finally taken.
Yours very truly,
Alumnus.
To the Editor of The News-Letter:
May I give my reasons for opposing the ;,,,doption in the Johns Hopkins University of the so-called"Hon
or System," which several of your
correspondents have advocated?
Surely, when we reflect a moment,
we shall see that the present method
of conducting examinations is much
more of an honor system than the
system used in some other institutions, and advocated by your correspondents. At present the student has
simply his own will to keep him from
dishonesty in his examinations. There
are, to be sure, professors in the
room; but they show us clearly that
they are not there to watch us. Witn
the introduction of this new system,
the student has not only his own will,
but the fear of the penalty to keep
him from dishonesty. So the question resolves itself: Is it better that
a student be given a chance to control his own will, with his own conscience as a judge, or that he be
forced, by fear, to do right. The
one method gives the student the opportunity to strengthen his will-power or to weaken it; the other method
takes away this opportunity, and allows him neither to strengthen nor
weaken it. Which is the better? The
answer to this question depends upon
whether the proportion of students
who strengthen themselves is greater
or less than that of those who weaken themselves. From the observations that I have made, I believe that
at least ninety per cent of the students are perfectly honest in their
examinations. It hardly seems fair
that this vast majority should have
their opportunity for development restricted by the comparatively small
number who must be forced to do
right.
Student.
